articles.headline: Victims Who Deserve Their Fate
articles.snippet: “Let the buyer beware” as a concept is staging a comeback as the trustee in the Madoff case argues that some investors were sophisticated enough to know it was a Ponzi scheme.
articles.abstract: “Let the buyer beware” as a concept is staging a comeback as the trustee in the Madoff case argues that some investors were sophisticated enough to know it was a Ponzi scheme.
articles.lead_paragraph: The securities laws of the United States “substitute a philosophy of disclosure for the philosophy of caveat emptor,” Justice Arthur Goldberg wrote in a Supreme Court decision nearly half a century ago.

articles.headline: Hospitals Shift Smoking Bans to Smoker Ban
articles.snippet: More hospitals and medical businesses in many states are adopting strict policies that make smoking a reason to turn away job applicants.
articles.abstract: More hospitals and medical businesses in many states are adopting strict policies that make smoking a reason to turn away job applicants.
articles.lead_paragraph: Smokers now face another risk from their habit: it could cost them a shot at a job.

articles.headline: Tyson Settles U.S. Charges of Bribery
articles.snippet: The case involved accusations that the company’s subsidiary in Mexico made payoffs to get products certified for export.
articles.abstract: The case involved accusations that the company’s subsidiary in Mexico made payoffs to get products certified for export.
articles.lead_paragraph: When top executives of Tyson Foods discovered that the company’s Mexican chicken plants were paying bribes to government inspectors, they not only allowed the practice to continue, they formed a committee to find a more acceptable way to make the illicit payments, according to federal court documents released on Thursday.

articles.headline: In China, Tentative Steps Toward Global Currency
articles.snippet: Beijing has begun to loosen currency controls, which could strengthen China’s influence in financial markets.
articles.abstract: Beijing has begun to loosen currency controls, which could strengthen China’s influence in financial markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Now that it has passed Japan to become the world’s second-largest economy after the United States, China is considering the next step as a world power: making its money a global currency.

articles.headline: Republican Leaders Yield to a Push for More Budget Cuts
articles.snippet: The agreement by House leaders on Thursday showed the power of the Tea Party movement and increased the chances of a major fiscal clash with Democrats.
articles.abstract: The agreement by House leaders on Thursday showed the power of the Tea Party movement and increased the chances of a major fiscal clash with Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  House Republican leaders said Thursday that they would accede to demands from conservatives and dig deeper into the federal budget for billions of dollars in additional savings this year, exhibiting the power of the Tea Party movement and increasing chances of a major fiscal clash with Democrats.

articles.headline: Web Words That Lure the Readers
articles.snippet: The sale of the Huffington Post has drawn new attention to the use of behind-the-scenes tactics to get search engine users to visit Web sites.
articles.abstract: The sale of the Huffington Post has drawn new attention to the use of behind-the-scenes tactics to get search engine users to visit Web sites.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Huffington Post has hired veteran journalists to beef up its news coverage. But a significant chunk of its readers come instead for articles like one published this week: “Chelsy Davy & Prince Harry: So Happy Together?”

articles.headline: Obama Faces a Stark Choice on Mubarak
articles.snippet: The administration is under pressure to choose between a defiant ally and the democratic aspirations of protesters.
articles.abstract: The administration is under pressure to choose between a defiant ally and the democratic aspirations of protesters.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Hosni Mubarak’s refusal to step down on Thursday, after a day of rumors galvanized the crowds in Cairo, confronts the Obama administration with a stark choice: break decisively with Mr. Mubarak or stick to its call for an “orderly transition” that may no longer be tenable.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Egypt Erupts in Jubilation as Mubarak Steps Down
articles.snippet: The departure of President Hosni Mubarak was a pivotal turn in a revolt that has upended one of the Arab’s world’s most enduring dictatorships.
articles.abstract: The departure of President Hosni Mubarak was a pivotal turn in a revolt that has upended one of the Arab’s world’s most enduring dictatorships.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  An 18-day-old revolt led by the young people of Egypt ousted President Hosni Mubarak on Friday, shattering three decades of political stasis here and overturning the established order of the Arab world.

articles.headline: Administration Calls for Cutting Aid to Home Buyers
articles.snippet: Officials said they concluded the country could not afford to sustain its commitment to minting homeowners. Better to help some people rent.
articles.abstract: Officials said they concluded the country could not afford to sustain its commitment to minting homeowners. Better to help some people rent.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration’s much-anticipated report on redesigning the government’s role in housing finance, published Friday, is not solely a proposal to dissolve the unpopular finance companies Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.

articles.headline: Galloping Growth, and Hunger in India
articles.snippet: Four decades after the Green Revolution, nearly half of Indian children under 6 are malnourished.
articles.abstract: Four decades after the Green Revolution, nearly half of Indian children under 6 are malnourished.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAMNOD, India — The 50-year-old farmer knew from experience that his onion crop was doomed when torrential rains pounded his fields throughout September, a month when the Indian monsoon normally peters out.
